data.title: Add a Bracket higlight feature on scroll bar

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: When you select an object/variable, etc it shows it highlighted on the scroll bar.  Could you also do this for brackets { } ?  That way you know where a bracket opens and closes.  I us brackets in PHP, javascript, JQuery, CSS, etc.

data.title: Show a prompt when file changes on disk
data.body:
Add a prompt if another person has modified the file you are working on - Notepad++ has this feature.  Then  you have the option to continue, or reload the file.

Also add a way to open include files directly in the document.  This is a big feature in Adobe DreamWeaver.

data.title: Add ability to exclude files from "quick open" (cmd-p)
data.body:
Similar to the way you can exclude files from search (`search.exclude`) and workspace (`files.exclude`), it would be really nice to be able to exclude files from quick open (`cmd-p`).

My use case is that I have files like I like to be able to access rarely from the explorer pane (configuration and generated code), but I don't ever want them to show up in the quick open list.

data.title: IIS Web Language don't have highlight
data.body:
I'm using Visual Studio Code open a IIS web page,But it don't hava highlight.
I hope you support that language.

data.title: Consider removing full screen toggle from Zen Mode
data.body:
Regarding #15647 

- VSCode Version:
1.8.0 Insiders
- OS Version:
10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  toggle zen mode

As of today (Nov 29) zen mode also toggles full screen display. I would prefer that it _does not_ change the full screen state. 

I actually use VSCode in full screen mode with split screen mode (together with Firefox) and Zen Mode toggle destroys this layout.

data.title: Untitled files restore badly with associated file path when bypassing stacks restore
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. run from the command line code `<folder> <file that does not exit>` 
2. quit
3. run from the command line code `<folder> <another file that does not exit>` 

=> the file from step 1. shows up with a full path because we fail to restore the associated file path

data.title: Better highlighting on errors to spot them faster
data.body:
Hi there!

I've been experiencing a problem when highlighting errors on VSCode. Whenever you have big issues you can spot them on the fly when opening the document. But if your issues are small, you need more time to spot those errors.

As you can see in the image below, these 2 lines have 2 errors and both of them have the problem of not having a semicolon at the end of the line:
![screen shot 2016-11-29 at 15 45 30](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8843202/20714411/41aa18f2-b64c-11e6-8189-33bf5d188231.png)

The first one is easier to spot than the second (at the end of the parenthesis). The simpler solution for this would be to highlight the entire line in some way (so double highlight) just to spot easily the lines that have errors.

Atom does this the following way:
![screen shot 2016-11-29 at 15 48 21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8843202/20714571/afd983e4-b64c-11e6-931c-66c0ae556576.png)

Thanks and keep up the good work!

- VSCode Version: Version 1.7.2
- OS Version: 10.12.1 (macOS Sierra)

data.title: Code folding gets confused when code isn't properly indented
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.8.0-insider (4721762a2ac1e21f1e33094e810d4888052f3d8d, 2016-11-29T07:09:36.481Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14971
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.1.0|
|theme-dracula|dracula-theme|1.2.5|
|eval|Stormspirit|0.0.5|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type a JavaScript function and put misaligned code in the middle of the function
2. Click on the `+` to fold the function

What happens ?
Code only hides the code up to the mis-aligned comment: what's next isn't hidden although it's part of the function and should be hidden.

See:
![cold-folding](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/20714326/f4ae74bc-b64b-11e6-96c6-cd7c57d5ae90.gif)

data.title: end of central directory record signature not found
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
Version 1.8.0-insider (1.8.0-insider)
`4721762a2ac1e21f1e33094e810d4888052f3d8d`
2016-11-29T07:03:09.021Z
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

@joaomoreno I'm seeing this error, `end of central directory record signature not found,` attempting to update any extension today. 

The relevant portion of my user settings is:

`    "http.proxy": "http://localhost:3128/",
    "https.proxy": "http://localhost:3128",    
    "http.proxyStrictSSL": false,`

The localhost proxy is a Cntlm authentication proxy (https://sourceforge.net/projects/cntlm/) to our NTLM corporate proxy.

I'm not seeing any network requests in the VS Code developer tools window, so I'm unsure of what might be causing this. If I break in net.js at line 729 where the call to createWriteReq() starts, I get the following `data` parameter on Beautify (for example - it's similar on all other extensions):

`"{"id":50,"type":0,"channelName":"extensions","name":"installFromGallery","arg":[{"id":"697255a9-3f36-44c8-b084-d3b91edfb23a","name":"beautify","version":"0.6.2","date":"2016-11-28T04:23:10.43Z","displayName":"beautify","publisherId":"901b401e-7657-4a33-8c9a-0854c569607e","publisher":"HookyQR","publisherDisplayName":"HookyQR","description":"Beautify code in place for VS Code","installCount":339711,"rating":4.625,"ratingCount":24,"assets":{"manifest":"https://hookyqr.gallerycdn.vsassets.io/extensions/hookyqr/beautify/0.6.2/1480306987732/Microsoft.VisualStudio.Code.Manifest","readme":"https://hookyqr.gallerycdn.vsassets.io/extensions/hookyqr/beautify/0.6.2/1480306987732/Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.Content.Details","download":"https://hookyqr.gallerycdn.vsassets.io/extensions/hookyqr/beautify/0.6.2/1480306987732/Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.VSIXPackage?install=true","icon":"https://hookyqr.gallerycdn.vsassets.io/extensions/hookyqr/beautify/0.6.2/1480306987732/Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.Icons.Default?redirect=true","iconFallback":"https://hookyqr.gallerycdn.vsassets.io/extensions/hookyqr/beautify/0.6.2/1480306987732/Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.Icons.Default","license":"https://hookyqr.gallerycdn.vsassets.io/extensions/hookyqr/beautify/0.6.2/1480306987732/Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.Content.License"},"properties":{"dependencies":[],"engine":"^1.6.0"}},true]}"`

Opening the `download` URL in that parameter in my browser downloads the zip file successfully.

Also referenced this issue in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/2384#issuecomment-263580095.

Test: snippets in launch.json
data.body:
- [x] any os @aeschli  
- [x] any os @chrmarti 

Complexity: 1

As per https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13886 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15974 we are now supporting snippets in 'launch.json'. Have a workspace with a 'launch.json' file and verify:
* You get snipetts as suggestions once you trigger intelli-sense inside the `'configurations'` array
* You can easily add a new configuration by clicking on the green 'Add Configuration' button
* Once you choose a snippet the editor goes into snippert insert mode and you can navigate through the attributes that should be edited

data.title: JSON should automatically insert a comma after a snippet
data.body:
1. launch.json, trigger suggestions in the `'configurations'` array
2. Choose any snippet
3. Notice how the comma is not automatically inserted

data.title: JSON should not replace ${workspaceRoot} as a snippet insert value
data.body:
Latest vscode insiders

1. Open launch.json, trigger snippets inside the `'configurations'` array
2. Choose node.js launch configuration
3. Notice how the `${workspaceRoot}` is treated as a snippet insert value
4. This was previously possible and since now snippets require a `${number:name}` syntax the snippet content should not be treated as an insert value if it does not have a number

data.title: Test: "Just my Code" feature of node and node2
data.body:
Test for #3215:

- [x] Windows - **@ramya-rao-a**
- [x] OS X - **@chrmarti** 
- [x] Linux - **@Tyriar** 

Complexity: 3

The VS Code node debuggers (Node Debug and Node Debug 2) now support a feature similar to Visual Studio's "Just my Code" feature. With this you can easily skip over "uninteresting" code when debugging.
The feature is enabled by specifying the skipped code through a set of glob patterns for a `skipFiles` attribute. Positive patterns (e.g. `foo/**/*.js`) add to the set of skipped files, while negative patterns (e.g. `!foo/**/bar.js`) subtract from that set. In the following "skipped code" means code that is covered by the `skipFiles` glob patterns.

If skipped code is enabled, debugging is affected in the following way:
- if you step into skipped code, VS Code will continue to 'step in' until it reaches code that is not skipped.
- If you have a breakpoint in skipped code, the debugger will still break at that breakpoint and you can step manually inside the skipped code until you 'continue' or step out of it.
- You won't break on caught exceptions thrown in skipped code.

Verify that:
- the feature works as described both for debug type `node`and `node2`

data.title: tmTheme highlighting issues in vscode (Material Theme)
data.body: [The Material Theme from the tmTheme editor](http://tmtheme-editor.herokuapp.com/#!/editor/theme/Material%20Theme) doesn't render as intended per the tmTheme specs in vscode. I'm not sure if these themes are supposed to render in vscode exactly like they appear in the mtTheme editor? - VSCode Version: 1.7.2 - OS Version: Windows 10, macOS Sierra/El Capitan Steps to Reproduce: 1. Download and install extension "Material Theme" by Fredrik Averpil (that's me) 2. Enable extension and switch theme to "Material Theme" 3. Copy paste the following and set syntax to Python: ```python def hello(some_option=None): """docstring here""" call_some_function(with_arg='some_string') self.call_other_function(with_arg='some_string') some_object.call_yet_another_function(with_arg='some_string') ``` ### Expected highlighting As per Sublime Text: ...and tmTheme-Editor: #### Note The docstring is rendered differently in Sublime Text, which I guess is because of a customization for Sublime, so please disregard this. ### Actual highlighting in vscode: #### Issues with vscode highlighting * Function arguments are not highlighted in orange (instead they are red) * Strings inside function calls are not highlighted in green (instead they are blue) * Objects are not highlighted in blue (instead they are white) ### Additional information The extension is using the exact same `.tmTheme` theme which can be downloaded from the [tmTheme-editor](http://tmtheme-editor.herokuapp.com/#!/editor/theme/Material%20Theme). The theme is also maintained by Mattia Astorino and can be found in his git repo [here](https://github.com/equinusocio/material-theme/blob/develop/schemes/Material-Theme.tmTheme). The theme file from tmTheme-editor and from Mattia's github repo are very similar and they both produce the same highlighting issue in vscode.
